inputs.name: github_token
inputs.description: The GitHub token used to create an authenticated client - Provided for you by default!

inputs.name: status
inputs.description: The status of the GitHub Actions - For use in the post run workflow - Provided for you by default!

inputs.name: command
inputs.description: The string to look for in comments as an IssueOps trigger/command. Example: ".lint"

inputs.name: reaction
inputs.description: If set, the specified emoji "reaction" is put on the comment to indicate that the trigger was detected. For example, "rocket" or "eyes"

inputs.name: success_reaction
inputs.description: The reaction to add to the comment that triggered the Action if its execution was successful

inputs.name: failure_reaction
inputs.description: The reaction to add to the comment that triggered the Action if its execution failed

inputs.name: allowed_contexts
inputs.description: A comma separated list of comment contexts that are allowed to trigger this IssueOps command. Pull requests and issues are the only currently supported contexts

inputs.name: permissions
inputs.description: The allowed GitHub permissions an actor can have to invoke IssueOps commands - Example: "write,admin"

inputs.name: allow_drafts
inputs.description: Whether or not to allow this IssueOps command to be run on draft pull requests

inputs.name: allow_forks
inputs.description: Whether or not to allow this IssueOps command to be run on forked pull requests

inputs.name: skip_ci
inputs.description: Whether or not to require passing CI checks before this IssueOps command can be run

inputs.name: skip_reviews
inputs.description: Whether or not to require reviews before this IssueOps command can be run

inputs.name: param_separator
inputs.description: The separator to use for parsing parameters in comments in IssueOps commands. Parameters will are saved as outputs and can be used in subsequent steps

inputs.name: allowlist
inputs.description: A comma separated list of GitHub usernames or teams that should be allowed to use the IssueOps commands configured in this Action. If unset, then all users meeting the "permissions" requirement will be able to run commands. Example: "monalisa,octocat,my-org/my-team"

inputs.name: allowlist_pat
inputs.description: A GitHub personal access token with "read:org" scopes. This is only needed if you are using the "allowlist" option with a GitHub org team. For example: "my-org/my-team"

inputs.name: skip_completing
inputs.description: If set to "true", skip the process of completing the Action. This is useful if you want to customize the way this Action completes - For example, custom reactions, comments, etc

inputs.name: fork_review_bypass
inputs.description: If set to "true", allow forks to bypass the review requirement if the operation is being made on a pull request from a fork. This option is potentially dangerous if you are checking out code in your workflow as a result of invoking this Action. If the code you are checking out has not been reviewed, then you might open yourself up to a TOCTOU vulnerability. You should always ensure that the code you are checking out has been reviewed, and that you checkout an exact commit sha rather than a ref.

outputs.name: triggered
outputs.description: The string "true" if the trigger was found, otherwise the string "false" - Just because the workflow was triggered does not mean it should continue. This is a step 1/2 check

outputs.name: continue
outputs.description: The string "true" if the workflow should continue, otherwise empty - Use this to conditionally control if your workflow should proceed or not. This is a step 2/2 check

outputs.name: actor
outputs.description: The GitHub handle of the actor that invoked the IssueOps command

outputs.name: params
outputs.description: The raw parameters that were passed into the IssueOps command

outputs.name: comment_id
outputs.description: The comment id which triggered this action

outputs.name: issue_number
outputs.description: The issue number which this Action was triggered on

outputs.name: initial_reaction_id
outputs.description: The reaction id for the initial reaction on the trigger comment

outputs.name: fork
outputs.description: The string "true" if the pull request is a fork, otherwise "false"

outputs.name: fork_ref
outputs.description: The true ref of the fork

outputs.name: fork_label
outputs.description: The API label field returned for the fork

outputs.name: fork_checkout
outputs.description: The console command presented in the GitHub UI to checkout a given fork locally

outputs.name: fork_full_name
outputs.description: The full name of the fork in "org/repo" format

outputs.name: sha
outputs.description: The commit sha if being used in the context of a pull request

outputs.name: ref
outputs.description: The ref if being used in the context of a pull request

outputs.name: base_ref
outputs.description: The base ref that the pull request is merging into (if available and run in the context of a pull request)
